title: How to Plant Boxwood

steps.headline: Decide whether to plant boxwood in a garden or a pot.
steps.description: This does not change the manner of planting drastically, but the mobility of a potted plant might suit your needs better than boxwood rooted in the ground.

steps.headline: Choose the correct time to plant.
steps.description: Fall is the ideal season for planting boxwood, but it can also be successfully planted in spring or early summer.

steps.headline: Determine where to plant.
Test your soil.
steps.description: The optimal pH level of the soil is slightly acidic, around 6 or 7 on the scale. Thick, fertile soil is best. The soil should also drain well, as boxwood's short roots require quick drainage so they do not drown.

steps.headline: Loosen the ball of roots on a new boxwood plant so they are mostly spread out.
steps.description: If the plant is a transplant, skip this step.

steps.headline: Dig a hole in the soil about as deep as the plant's height and as wide as the spread of the roots.
steps.description: If you are planting the boxwood in a pot, place the root ball into shrub soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) deep.

steps.headline: Place the boxwood inside the hole and cover the roots with water and soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) short of the top.
Pour 2 inches (5.08 cm) of mulch into the remainder of the hole and pack it down.
Water the boxwood once a week during warm months and much less often during cooler periods.

text:
Decide whether to plant boxwood in a garden or a pot. This does not change the manner of planting drastically, but the mobility of a potted plant might suit your needs better than boxwood rooted in the ground. Choose the correct time to plant. Fall is the ideal season for planting boxwood, but it can also be successfully planted in spring or early summer. Determine where to plant. Depending on the type of climate in your region, you might be limited in where you can plant boxwood. If you live in a colder area, boxwood should be planted in a location where it will receive full sunlight. Also consider positioning the plant where it will be protected from cold wind. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} In warmer areas, boxwood should be planted where it will receive partial shade. In all regions, boxwood should be planted exposed to the north or south. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Test your soil. The optimal pH level of the soil is slightly acidic, around 6 or 7 on the scale. Thick, fertile soil is best. The soil should also drain well, as boxwood's short roots require quick drainage so they do not drown. Loosen the ball of roots on a new boxwood plant so they are mostly spread out. If the plant is a transplant, skip this step. Dig a hole in the soil about as deep as the plant's height and as wide as the spread of the roots. If you are planting the boxwood in a pot, place the root ball into shrub soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) deep. Place the boxwood inside the hole and cover the roots with water and soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) short of the top. Pour 2 inches (5.08 cm) of mulch into the remainder of the hole and pack it down. Water the boxwood once a week during warm months and much less often during cooler periods.
sentences: Decide whether to plant boxwood in a garden or a pot.
This does not change the manner of planting drastically, but the mobility of a potted plant might suit your needs better than boxwood rooted in the ground.
Choose the correct time to plant.
Fall is the ideal season for planting boxwood, but it can also be successfully planted in spring or early summer.
Determine where to plant.
Depending on the type of climate in your region, you might be limited in where you can plant boxwood.
If you live in a colder area, boxwood should be planted in a location where it will receive full sunlight.
Also consider positioning the plant where it will be protected from cold wind.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d4\/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/d4\/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} In warmer areas, boxwood should be planted where it will receive partial shade.
In all regions, boxwood should be planted exposed to the north or south.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Plant-Boxwood-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Test your soil.
The optimal pH level of the soil is slightly acidic, around 6 or 7 on the scale.
Thick, fertile soil is best.
The soil should also drain well, as boxwood's short roots require quick drainage so they do not drown.
Loosen the ball of roots on a new boxwood plant so they are mostly spread out.
If the plant is a transplant, skip this step.
Dig a hole in the soil about as deep as the plant's height and as wide as the spread of the roots.
If you are planting the boxwood in a pot, place the root ball into shrub soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) deep.
Place the boxwood inside the hole and cover the roots with water and soil about 2 inches (5.08 cm) short of the top.
Pour 2 inches (5.08 cm) of mulch into the remainder of the hole and pack it down.
Water the boxwood once a week during warm months and much less often during cooler periods.
tyn_section: Outdoor tree and shrub potting soil
